title-group.article-title: Effect of linear thermal gradient on vibrations of trapezoidal plates whose thickness varies parabolically

article-meta.aff: Department of Mathematics, MS College, India

author-notes.corresp: Arun Kumar Gupta, Department of Mathematics, MS College, Saharanpur-247001, India Email:gupta_arunnitin@yahoo.co.in

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2010 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Plates of variable thickness are widely used in modern technology nowadays in various engineering fields, such as marine engineering, aeronautical fields, nuclear reactors etc. The present paper is a study of linear thermal gradient on the vibration of trapezoidal plates with parabolically varying thickness. The Rayleigh Ritz technique is used to get the required frequency equation. In the present investigation, the effect of various factors, i.e. thermal gradient, taper constant and aspect ratio are studied to calculate the frequencies corresponding to the first two modes of vibration and are presented in tabular and graphical form.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: In this era of science and technology, plates of various shapes and of variable thickness may be regarded as a first approximation to wings and blades and occur as panels in many forms of engineering structures. Thus knowledge of their natural frequencies is of considerable importance at the design stage in order to avoid resonance excited by internal or external forces. The literature shows that sufficient work is available on free vibration analysis of plates of different shapes such as rectangular plates, elliptic plates and circular plates etc. In comparison to these plates trapezoidal plates have received less attention. Klein (1955) worked on the vibration of simply supported trapezoidal flat plates. Leissa (1969) has reported the natural frequencies of isotropic cantilevered trapezoidal plates. Saliba (1986) worked on free vibration analysis of simply supported symmetrical trapezoidal plates. Saliba (1988) worked on transverse free vibration of fully clamped symmetrical trapezoidal plates. Liew and Lam (1991) studied the transverse vibration of isotropic and anisotropic trapezoidal plates using orthogonal plate functions with the Rayleigh Ritz approach. Krishnan and Deshpande (1991) studied the free vibration of trapezoidal plates. Liew and Lim (1993) have studied the transverse vibration of trapezoidal plates of variable thickness: Symmetric trapezoids. Lim and Liew (1995) studied the vibration of pretwisted cantilever trapezoidal symmetric laminates. Bambill et al. (1998) studied the transverse vibrations of rectangular, trapezoidal and triangular orthotropic cantilever plates. Jain and Soni (1973) discovered the free vibrations of rectangular plates of parabolically varying thickness. Tomar et al. (1984) studied the free vibrations of an isotropic non- homogeneous infinite plate of parabolically varying thickness. Singh and Jain (2004) have studied the free asymmetric transverse vibration of parabolically varying thickness of polar orthotropic annular plate with flexible edge conditions. Kumar and Tomar (2006) studied the free transverse vibrations of monoclinic rectangular plates with continuously varying thickness and density. Gupta et al. (2006) studied the vibration analysis of non-homogeneous circular plate of nonlinear thickness variation by the differential quadrature method. Gupta et al. (2007) have studied the thermal effect on vibration of non-homogeneous orthotropic rectangular plate having bi-directional parabolically varying thickness. Feng and Min (2008) have studied the vibrations of axially moving visco-elastic plate with parabolically varying thickness. Gupta et al. (2010) studied the vibration of visco-elastic parallelogram plate with parabolic thickness variation. Bhatnagar and Gupta (1988) analyzed the vibration of visco-elastic circular plate subjected to a thermal gradient. Gupta and Sharma (2010) studied the effect of a thermal gradient on the vibration of trapezoidal plate of linearly varying thickness. Tomar and Gupta (1985) studied the effect of a thermal gradient on frequencies of an orthotropic rectangular plate whose thickness varies in two directions. Gupta and Khanna (2007) solved the problem of visco-elastic rectangular plate with linearly thickness variations in both directions.

It should be noted that until now no author has discussed the effect of temperature on the vibration of trapezoidal plate with varying thickness. Therefore a study is being presented to determine the natural frequencies for the first two modes of vibration on the basis of Classical plate theory. The Rayleigh Ritz technique is used to calculate the natural frequencies with a two term deflection function.

The trapezoidal plate considered here is C-S-C-S boundary condition. Frequencies are calculated for different values of taper constant, thermal gradient and aspect ratio. Results are shown in tabular and graphical form and are verified by comparison with data available in the literature.

sec.title: 2. Method of analysis
sec.p:
Consider a symmetric trapezoidal plate of varying thickness. It is assumed that variation in thickness of the plate is parabolically in one direction. The geometry of the plate is as shown in Figure 1. The expression for parabolically varying thickness is presented in the form of equation (1). (1) where h0 the maximum plate thickness is occurs at left edge & α h0 is the minimum plate thickness occurring at the right edge, α is the taper constant. Figure 1.
Geometry of trapezoidal plate with variable thickness.

sec.title: 2.1. Mathematical formulation
sec.p: With the assumption that the temperature of the trapezoidal plates varies in x direction linearly then τ can be expressed as (2)

Introducing non-dimensional variables ξ=xa and η=yb equation (2) becomes (3) where τ denotes the temperature excess above the reference temperature at a distance ξ=xa and τ0 denotes the temperature excess above the reference temperature at the end ξ=−12.

The temperature dependence of the modulus of elasticity for most of engineering materials is as given by Nowacki (1962) is (4) where E0 is the value of Young’s modulus along the reference temperature i.e. at τ = 0 and γ is the slope of the variation of E with γ.
Using (3) into (4) the modulus variation (4) becomes (5) where β=γτ0 (0≤β≤1), known as thermal gradient.

The governing differential equation for kinetic energy V and strain energy T as given by Liew and Lim (1993) are (6) and (7) in which D(ξ) is the flexural rigidity of the plate, which is given by (8) where (9) is the flexural rigidity of the plate at the side ξ=−12, υ is the Poisson ratio, A is the area of the plate, ρ is the mass density per unit area of the plate and ω is the angular frequency of vibration.
From equations (5) and (9) one gets (10) using (10) in (8) (11)
Substituting the value of D(ξ) and h(ξ) in (6) and (7) respectively (12) (13)

sec.title: 2.2. Solution of equation
sec.p: The two term deflection function is taken as (14) where A1 and A2 are constants.
To obtain the solution the Rayleigh Ritz technique is used which requires maximum strain energy be equal to the maximum kinetic energy i.e. (15)
For trapezoidal plates whose two edges are clamped and two are simply supported boundaries are defined by four straight lines (16)
Equation (14) is so chosen to satisfy the boundary condition of the plate. Using boundary conditions (16) the expression for V and T becomes (17) (18)
Now equation (15) becomes (19) where (20) (21) and λ2 is a frequency parameter given by
Equation (19) contains two unknown parameter A1 and A2, which can be evaluated in the following way:
Solution of equation (23) is given by
Here cm1 and cm2 involves parametric constant and frequency parameters. It is desirable for a non-zero solution that the coefficient of (24) must be zero. So one gets the frequency equation as
From equation (25) one can obtain a quadratic equation in λ2 from which the two values of λ2 can be found.

sec.title: 3. Results and discussion
sec.p: The natural frequencies are calculated for the first two modes of vibration for a trapezoidal plate, whose thickness varies parabolically, for various values of taper constants, thermal gradient and aspect ratio. All these results are shown in the form of tables and graphs. The Poisson ratio is to be taken as 0.33.

The results are calculated with great concentration and accuracy using latest computer technology. These results are tabulated in Tables 1–6 and plotted graphically in Figures 2–7. Figure 2.
Variation of frequency parameter with taper constant for a trapezoidal plate, having parabolically varying thinkness: (a) first mode (b) second mode. Table 1.
Values of frequency parameter ‘λ’ for different values of taper constant ‘α’ and constant aspect ratio a/b = 1.0, c/b = 0.5
β = 0.0 β = 0.4
α First mode Second mode First mode Second mode
0.0 35.065961 182.746902 33.450525 170.025133
0.2 35.374321 186.662068 33.634732 173.038890
0.4 35.846026 191.465274 33.949766 176.829402
0.6 36.494075 197.072435 34.404101 181.312931
0.8 37.324931 203.403628 35.002254 186.413969
1.0 38.339103 210.384004 35.745009 192.664490

Tables 1 and 2 show that with an increase in the taper constant α the frequency parameter increases for both modes of vibration. The results have been shown for the following two cases: Table 2.
Values of frequency parameter ‘λ’ for different values of taper constant ‘α’ and constant aspect ratio a/b = 1.0, c/b = 1.0
β = 0.0 β = 0.4

(i) β = 0.0 (ii) β = 0.4 and aspect ratio c/b = 0.5, 1.0, a/b = 1.0.
It is also seen that when aspect ratio c/b is increased from 0.5 to 1.0 the frequency parameter decreases for both modes of vibration.

Figures 2 and 3 represent the frequency parameter for both modes of vibration. It is also evident from Figures 2 and 3 that the frequency parameter increases with an increase of the taper constant. Figure 3.
Variation of frequency parameter with taper constant for a trapezoidal plate, having parabolically varying thinkness: (a) first mode (b) second mode.

Tables 3 and 4 represent variation of the frequency parameter with thermal gradient. As the thermal gradient increases the frequency parameter decreases for both modes of vibration. The results have been displayed for the following two cases: Table 3.

Also when the aspect ratio a/b is decreased from 1.0 to 0.5, the frequency parameter decreases for both modes of vibration.

After analyzing Figures 6 and 7 it can be concluded that when the aspect ratio c/b is increased the frequency parameter decreases for both modes of vibration. One can easily analyze from Figures 6 and 7 that the frequency parameter has a maximum value for α = 0.4, β = 0.0 and a minimum for α = 0.0, β = 0.4. Figure 6.
Variation of frequency parameter with aspect ratio for a trapezoidal plate, having parabolically varying thinkness: (a) first mode (b) second mode. Figure 7.
Variation of frequency parameter with aspect ratio for a trapezoidal plate, having parabolically varying thinkness: (a) first mode (b) second mode.

sec.title: 4. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, a general formulation has been presented to study the vibratory behavior of symmetric trapezoidal plates of parabolically varying thickness. This problem has been considered due to its practical application in engineering. In the mathematical formulation a two term deflection function has been used. The Rayleigh Ritz method with two term deflection function yields accurate frequencies for first and second mode of vibration. Effects of aspect ratio, taper constant and thermal gradient have been carefully examined.

From the above results it is clear that an increase in taper constant increases the frequency of vibration, whereas an increase in thermal gradient reduces the frequency of vibration. These observations are particularly important because trapezoidal plates are commonly used in modern technology nowadays. It provides valuable information for researchers and engineers in design applications.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
